awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Chemical Order/Disorder Enabled Phononic Memory in PbSc0.5Ta0.5O3
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates a new means to store computed information that is not sensitive to electromagnetic pulses. In this method heat is conducted through a material that can be in two different states. In one state, the material will have like atoms arranged in a specific order, while in the other state the atoms will inhabit random positions. Laser pulses are used to locally heat the material and transform it from one state to the other, which then serve as either on-state or off-state memories. It has been computationally predicted that solid solutions of various atoms will conduct heat differently depending on the chemical order, but has not been experimentally proven. This hardened computing method enhances information security and computing resiliency against unavoidable electromagnetic pulses, such as those resulting from solar flares. This project also seeks to educate the public on the magnitude of energy wasted as heat and how it can be harnessed and converted for useful energy.

This research project studies the role of chemical order on thermal conductivity in a material system where heat is carried by phonons, and will advanced the fundamental understanding of how local chemical order can be manipulated to achieve a desired phononic or thermal response. The material studied is lead scandium tantalate, a perovskite oxide that can be chemically ordered or disordered on the octahedrally coordinated cation site depending on the thermal history. The project employs epitaxial growth via pulsed laser ablation on single crystal strontium titanate substrates with an epitaxial strontium ruthanate conductive oxide electrode. Thermal conductivity evaluated using time domain thermoreflectance establishes the thermal conductivity of the lead scandium tantalate with varying degrees of chemical order. High energy optical laser pulses heat the lead scandium tantalate material locally resulting in spatial control of chemical order and thermal conductivity. The perovskite lead scandium tantalate is isostructural with lead zirconium titanate, which has been previously shown to serve as a phonon regulating material. This project develops the necessary perovskite thermal memory to accompany the thermal regulator, which is an important step toward developing a phonon computer. Furthermore, this research tests computational predictions that posit a chemically ordered material possesses a higher thermal conductivity at low temperatures than a disordered counterpart, but that will exhibit a cross-over in thermal conductivity at elevated temperatures, which is not yet experimentally validated. The ability to compute and store information via phonons is a potential path toward electro-magnetic pulse resilient computing, which is vital for information security.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Current computer memory technologies utilize either magnetic spin or electronic charge to store data that can be accessed, written, and rewritten. These mechanism of storing information are susceptible to disruption by electro-magnetic waves, such as that from a solar flare. It is desirable to have a robust means of storing information that could also be written and rewritten in a facile manner that is impervious to external stimuli, such as electro-magnetic waves. This project studied a material that could store information in the form of its thermal conductivity. Thermal conductivity, when heat is carried by atomic vibrations rather than electronic charge carriers, is impervious to electro-magnetic waves. Lead scandium tantalate is a material that can have the scandium and tantalum atoms randomly arranged or ordered in a specific arrangement. The random arrangement has a low thermal conductivity while the ordered arrangement is predicted to have a high thermal conductivity. The random arrangement may be transformed into the ordered arrangement with the application of heat. As such, one could utilize a local heat source to change the material from a low thermal conductivity state to a high thermal conductivity state. Heating and rapid cooling of the ordered arrangement could reverse this process. As such, computer memory that is based upon thermal conductivity could be developed. 

The intellectual merit of this work was the study of how the degree of the ordered atomic arrangement in an electrical insulating material changes the thermal conductivity. This will provide new insight into how heat conducts through materials. We found that we could alter the degree of atomic chemical order through annealing lead scandium tantalate layers at temperatures between 500 and 800 degrees centigrade. We were able to change the order from approximately 20% ordered to nearly 60% ordered. Measurement of the thermal conductivity revealed that the thermal conductivity did not change appreciably over this range of order. Our work suggests that much greater degrees of chemical order are needed to obtain a change in thermal conductivity and make this technology usable as a form of information storage. We also found that the time durations needed to achieve this order were very long (tens to hundreds of hours) and that alternative material systems may provide a better platform for such an application. While the desired result of a material capable of having two different thermal conductivity states that are stabilized by chemical order was not achieved, several outcomes occurred: 1) New knowledge regarding the necessary conditions to prepare thin layers of lead scandium tantalate was developed, 2) new understanding of the durations and temperatures needed to chemically order lead scandium tantalate was developed, 3) a new understanding of the degree of order necessary to observe an appreciable thermal conductivity change was developed, and 4) a demonstration of the utility of a second heating laser in thermal conductivity metrology was conducted.

Broader impacts of this project include the following: 1) New metrology methods for thermal conductivity characterization whereby a laser heating source can be used to heat a material locally, rather than using a furnace to heat an entire sample. This new metrology will enable facile material thermal property characterization and is amenable for use in structures that are either too large or too fragile for conventional characterization. 2) An understanding of the degree of chemical order needed to observe a thermal conductivity change was developed, showing that substantial degrees of order are necessary. This may impact material design for a broad range of applications beyond computing. 3) Students and post-doctoral scholars were educated in a diverse, multi-disciplinary team. This project resulted in the education of one post-doctoral scholar and three graduate research assistants.
